intro: Elodes crassifolia, commonly known as the broad-leaf waterweed, is a freshwater aquatic plant native to parts of Africa and Asia. It is characterized by its long, flexible stems and broad, lance-shaped leaves that are typically arranged in whorls. The plant produces small, inconspicuous flowers that are often submerged, followed by small, oval fruits containing numerous seeds. Elodes crassifolia is often found in still or slow-moving freshwater environments such as ponds and lakes. It plays an important role in aquatic ecosystems by providing habitat and oxygen for aquatic life.
